info.headline: Flood Advisory issued December 26 at 4:57AM EST until December 27 at 6:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON EST TODAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following county, Transylvania. * WHEN...Until noon EST Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 442 AM EST, Over the past few hours, showers have weakened across Transylvania County, allowing runoff to subside and smaller streams to crest, including the headwaters of the French Broad River near and above Rosman, the Little River near Cedar Mountain, and the Davidson River above Pisgah Forest. However, an axis of showers and thunderstorms is entering the area from the south, capable of producing periods of heavy rain. This rainfall will occur on top of 2-5 inches of rain which accumulated since yesterday morning. Heavy rainfall will exacerbate high flow conditions and likely cause new rises on elevated streams. As a result, nuisance flooding conditions are expected to return or become more widespread, with some Minor Flooding or more significant flooding of flood-prone areas possible. Therefore, the Flood Advisory will continue as this heavy rain develops over the area. - The French Broad River near Rosman is at 4.7 feet and falling slowly. The river crested at 5.7 feet at midnight. Action/Advisory Stage is 7.0 feet. This heavy rain entering the area is likely to cause new rises at Rosman, and it is possible Rosman will exceed Action/Advisory Stage. Similar conditions exist in the headwaters of the Little River near Cedar Mountain, where the river crested at Action/Advisory Stage and is currently slowly falling below 5.9 feet. Intense rainfall rates may result in an acceleration of stream rises as upper soils are already saturated from earlier rainfall. This may cause flash flooding to develop and a Flash Flood Warning may be necessary. If rapid stream rises are observed, avoid all low-lying areas near streams and be prepared to seek higher ground. Additional periods of heavier rainfall are possible through Tuesday afternoon. - Some locations that may experience nuisance flooding include... Brevard, Rosman, Gorges State Park, Lake Toxaway, Dupont State Forest, Pisgah Forest, Connestee, Balsam Grove, Cedar Mountain, and Penrose.
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
